title: E95-1033

sentences.text: We provide a unified account of sentence-level and text-level anaphora within the framework of a dependency-based grammar model .

Criteria for anaphora resolution within sentence boundaries rephrase major concepts from GB 's binding theory , while those for text-level anaphora incorporate an adapted version of a Grosz-Sidner-style focus model .

Entity-a_unified_account_of_sentence-lev.label: a unified account of sentence-level and text-level anaphora
aliases: a unified account of sentence-level and text-level anaphora
Entity-a_unified_account_of_sentence-lev.description: A unified account of sentence-level and text-level anaphora refers to a theoretical framework that integrates the resolution of anaphoric references within individual sentences and across larger text structures, utilizing principles from dependency-based grammar and adapting concepts from binding theory and focus models.

mentions.local_name: a unified account of sentence-level and text-level anaphora

Entity-adapted_version_of_a_grosz-sidner.label: adapted version of a Grosz-Sidner-style focus model
aliases: adapted version of a Grosz-Sidner-style focus model
Entity-adapted_version_of_a_grosz-sidner.description: The adapted version of a Grosz-Sidner-style focus model refers to a modified framework used for resolving anaphora in text-level discourse, integrating principles from the original Grosz-Sidner model to enhance understanding of focus and reference in language.

mentions.local_name: adapted version of a Grosz-Sidner-style focus model

Entity-grosz-sidner-style_focus_model.label: Grosz-Sidner-style focus model
Entity-grosz-sidner-style_focus_model.description: The Grosz-Sidner-style focus model is a theoretical framework used for anaphora resolution in linguistic analysis, particularly focusing on how context influences the interpretation of references in discourse.

Entity-dependency-based_grammar_model.label: dependency-based grammar model
Entity-dependency-based_grammar_model.description: A dependency-based grammar model is a linguistic framework that represents the grammatical structure of sentences through the relationships between words, focusing on the dependencies that exist between them.

Entity-gb.label: GB
Entity-gb.description: GB refers to Government and Binding theory, a theory in syntax and semantics that addresses the principles of sentence structure and anaphora resolution.

Entity-anaphora_resolution_within_senten.label: anaphora resolution within sentence boundaries
Entity-anaphora_resolution_within_senten.description: Anaphora resolution within sentence boundaries refers to the process of identifying and linking pronouns or other referring expressions to their antecedents within the same sentence.

Entity-text-level_anaphora.label: text-level anaphora
Entity-text-level_anaphora.description: Text-level anaphora refers to the linguistic phenomenon where a word or phrase in a text refers back to another word or phrase that was mentioned earlier in the same text, establishing a connection across sentences or larger discourse units.

Entity-binding_theory.label: binding theory
Entity-binding_theory.description: Binding theory is a linguistic theory that addresses the relationships between pronouns and the expressions with which they share reference, particularly focusing on the rules governing anaphora and the binding of variables in sentences.

Entity-anaphora_resolution.label: anaphora resolution
Entity-anaphora_resolution.description: Anaphora resolution is a linguistic process that involves determining the antecedent of an anaphoric expression within a text, enabling the understanding of references in language.

Entity-major_concept_from_gb_s_binding_t.label: major concepts from GB's binding theory
aliases: major concepts from GB's binding theory
Entity-major_concept_from_gb_s_binding_t.description: The major concepts from GB's binding theory refer to the foundational principles and rules that govern the relationships between pronouns and their antecedents in generative grammar, as proposed by Noam Chomsky in his Government and Binding framework.

mentions.local_name: major concepts from GB's binding theory

Entity-gb_s_binding_theory.label: GB's binding theory
Entity-gb_s_binding_theory.description: GB's binding theory is a component of Government and Binding theory in linguistics that addresses the principles governing the relationships between pronouns and their antecedents in terms of reference and binding.

Entity-anaphora.label: anaphora
Entity-anaphora.description: Anaphora is a linguistic phenomenon where a word or phrase refers back to another word or phrase earlier in the discourse, often used to maintain coherence and avoid repetition.

Entity-sentence_boundary.label: sentence boundaries
Entity-sentence_boundary.description: Sentence boundaries are the defined limits that separate individual sentences in written or spoken language, marking the end of one complete thought and the beginning of another.

summary: We provide a unified account of sentence-level and text-level anaphora within the framework of a dependency-based grammar model . Criteria for anaphora resolution within sentence boundaries rephrase major concepts from GB 's binding theory , while those for text-level anaphora incorporate an adapted version of a Grosz-Sidner-style focus model .

Predicate-provides.label: provides
Predicate-provides.description: The predicate 'provides' indicates a relationship in which the subject offers, supplies, or makes available the object. It suggests that the subject is a source or means through which the object is accessible or can be obtained, often implying a beneficial or supportive role in the context of the relationship.

Predicate-within_the_framework_of.label: within the framework of
Predicate-within_the_framework_of.description: The predicate 'within the framework of' indicates that the subject is being analyzed, understood, or developed in relation to a specific theoretical or conceptual structure represented by the object. It suggests that the subject's characteristics, principles, or phenomena are being contextualized or interpreted through the lens of the object, which serves as a guiding model or system.

Predicate-rephrases.label: rephrases
Predicate-rephrases.description: The predicate 'rephrases' indicates a transformative action where the subject takes an existing idea, concept, or statement and expresses it in a different form or wording, thereby clarifying, simplifying, or altering its presentation while retaining its original meaning. This process connects the subject and object by demonstrating how the subject can reinterpret or restate the object in a new linguistic structure.

Predicate-incorporates.label: incorporates
Predicate-incorporates.description: The predicate 'incorporates' signifies a relationship in which the subject integrates or includes elements from the object into its structure or function. This implies that the subject adopts certain characteristics, features, or components of the object, thereby enhancing or modifying its own nature or operation through this inclusion.

Predicate-is_related_to.label: is related to
Predicate-is_related_to.description: The predicate 'is related to' establishes a connection or association between the subject and the object, indicating that they share a relevant link, influence, or correlation in a particular context. This relationship can encompass various forms of interaction, such as conceptual, thematic, or functional ties, suggesting that understanding one may provide insights into the other.

skos:broader.label: has a broader term
skos:broader.description: The predicate 'has a broader term' establishes a hierarchical relationship between the subject and the object, indicating that the subject is a specific instance or aspect of a more general concept represented by the object. This relationship suggests that the object encompasses a wider category or classification that includes the subject, thereby illustrating the connection between specific and general terms within a conceptual framework.
